Titre: Cheval Blanc Paris ‚Äì Hotel Review - Travel - Country and Town House
Contenu:
The sumptuous Cheval Blanc Paris, outpost is a lesson in how to do luxury ‚Äì how could it be otherwise?

Read the C&TH Responsible Tourism Guide

Hotel Review: Cheval Blanc Paris

STAY

Occupying the 1930s Pont Neuf side of the legendary Samaritaine department store (beloved by all Parisians), LVMH-owned Cheval Blanc Paris has rattled the city‚Äôs luxury hotel scene. The bass note is casual contemporary-chic ‚Äì trainers pace through the rather austere, art-clad entrance, though they are most likely Celine or Fendi. The striking Samaritaine deco exterior remains, while inside Eduard Fran√ßois has worked his architectural magic, carving out vast, airy rooms and indulging his inside-out hallmark to thrilling effect. Suites‚Äô winter gardens tip over several city landmarks and the Seine‚Äôs daily bustle below, while inside Peter Marino enlisted an army of artisans to layer exquisite fabrics into a deceptively minimalist and calming picture, with lashings of contemporary art. The lavish use of rich materials in restrained hues throughout echoes the futuristic family homes of the modern elite, where avant-garde coffee tables, pricey art and multitudes of marble are softened by multi-generational antics.

Splashes of primary colours add a playful, artistic edge (not the bohemian type) and nowhere more so than in the lively Le Tout Paris restaurant, where tiles, coasters and leather chairs recall a Calder mobile. Cheval Blanc Paris‚Äô glory lies several floors down in the spa: Europe‚Äôs longest hotel pool with digital art rendering the wall invisible with an animated would-be view of the Seine. From the leather-bound flasks filled with ginger and mint infusions before bed to the special fridge for Evian face sprays, the attention to detail is staggering, and seriously raises the bar for future hotel stays.

This is the French-owned conglomerate‚Äôs wildly luxurious and successful hospitality project coming home to roost, where many of its Saint Barths, Saint Tropez or Courchevel clients live and socialise. As such Peter Marino commissioned several French artists and sewed local reference points throughout the design project: Thierry Drefus‚Äôs digital art installation animates the lift and Vik Muniz‚Äôs commissioned painting of the Eiffel Tower hangs in the lobby. Courtesy of its previous life as a department store, Le Jardin is a rooftop Eden of geraniums and hydrangeas for pretty Parisian sunsets. If you‚Äôre looking for Sun-King splendour, head to the palace hotels surrounding the Arc De Triomphe, or accept that a modern Marie Antoinette would probably drop her bags here instead.

EAT

Having sprinkled Cheval Blanc St Tropez‚Äô La Vague d‚ÄôOr in Michelin stardust, Arnaud Donkele now oversees three of the city hotel‚Äôs six restaurants. This includes a proud and polished Milanese seafood joint, Langosteria, convivial hot-spot, Le Tout Paris and three Michelin-starred Pl√®nitude ‚Äì a high-octane brothy, saucy show with a contemporary, crinkle-wooded take on a wine cellar, and a secret cheese room.

Serving breakfast, lunch and supper, Le Tout Paris is the beating heart of the hotel with splashes of Calder-like primary colours and sweeping Parisian views, from Notre Dame to the Tour Eiffel. Well-dressed locals and hotel guests mingle for haute riffs on French brasserie classics, such as steak frite (done three ways) and pocket-sized potato dauphinoise. The comte-stuffed Madeline garnished with a hazelnut tree flower sets the pitch of this ‚Äòbrasserie‚Äô, as does the lavishly marbled bar lined with glasses of Ruinart.

Just off the lobby, Limbar shows off Maxim Frederic‚Äôs pastry game during the colder months with afternoon tea, whereas Le Jardin is a summertime affair ‚Äì a vast, green space with a birds-eye view over the very best of Paris. Menus take their cue from tomatoes and strawberries, which are whipped into elaborate plates of tomato carpaccio or french toast and Iberico ham on a bed of gazpacho. Cocktails also embrace the summer theme (go for the Verbena olive oil pisco sour).

DO

Throw on a robe and deep cushioned slippers embroidered in golden thread and head down to the Dior spa for the gold-standard of potions and treatments. Thimble-sized glasses of superfood juices greet guests on the Dior cushion-studded sofas before they float behind a therapist up a buttermilk corridor. The signature microdermabrasion uses a high-tech (quick results) tool which gently vibrates over layers of dead skin. Or choose one of the three scents from fragrant silk coils in glass jars, which are skillfully worked into weary muscles and tense shoulders. Room themes delve into Dior‚Äôs heritage, such as the Granville, named after Christian Dior‚Äôs childhood hometown. A marble steam room and spacious sauna can cocoon spa guests for hours.

Having riffled through bathroom beauty drawers and lathered on every delicious hair mask and body scrub designed by Dior perfumer Fran√ßois Demachy, guests can make the most of the neighbourhood (a boon for those less enamoured by Paris‚Äô Arc-de-Triomphe crowds). Cheval Blanc Paris sits between the trendy Marais, the Louvre (an art-lover‚Äôs labyrinth) and Isle de La Cit√©, where the iconic and slowly recovering Notre Dame sits amid a cluster of restaurants and independent boutiques. Head to Mus√©e des Artes D√©coratifs for high-octane exhibitions of fashion designers‚Äô life and works, such as Elsa Schiaparelli or cross the river into Saint Germain‚Äôs ancient streets, thrumming with design shops and low-key brasseries. Serious shoppers are granted private access to La Samaritaine‚Äôs haul of designer garbs from the hotel, through a Narnia-like door.

FAMILY FRIENDLY

Despite an austere design mission, Cheval Blanc is surprisingly family-friendly. Few Parisian palace hotels have mastered the kids club, or even entertained the notion, but Cheval Blanc‚Äôs nirvana of fancy dress, pet salamanders and toys galore is a hit with families. What‚Äôs more, elsewhere in the hotel, brightly-coloured pool floats line up next to flawlessly white sun loungers, nappies and a changing mat sit alongside marble loos with heavy, mirrored doors and smoky-scented hand creams. The message is clear: parents shouldn‚Äôt forgo the exquisite Cheval Blanc experience (and the hotel is wise to observe a cultural shift with well-to-do families increasingly travelling with sprogs in tow).

THE FINAL WORD

As a group, Cheval Blanc has mastered softening extraordinary and wildly elaborate scenes with a smart-casual code. Its aloof, gallery-like interiors and angular furniture thaw with this tangible mood, which renders everything, from the golden-topped beauty balms to the intricately layered pain au chocolat, even more phenomenal.

Titre: The big interview: Laurent Boillot, Hennessy CEO - The Spirits Business
Contenu:
Feature

By Melita Kiely

Having spent two years in lockdowns in Cognac, Hennessy CEO Laurent Boillot has immersed himself in the brand. Now, thanks to tie-ups with Harrods and the NBA, he is taking the company‚Äôs message global.

*This feature was originally published in the July 2022 issue of The Spirits Business

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs high pressure, but it‚Äôs great pressure,‚Äù says Laurent Boillot, CEO of Hennessy Cognac, about being at the top of the category. In June, Hennessy was given the prestigious title of Cognac Brand Champion in The Brand Champions 2022 annual report. Owned by Mo√´t Hennessy, the wine‚Äêand‚Äêspirits arm of LVMH, the brand sits several million cases ahead of its closest Cognac competitors.

‚ÄúWe have been able to put ourselves into the number‚Äêone position of the spirits business, and it‚Äôs about staying there,‚Äù Boillot says. ‚ÄúIf we do our job well, we can stay number one, and probably even increase the gap between us and the others. And the competition is not only Cognac, it‚Äôs all wine and spirits; the whole spirits industry.‚Äù

Boillot became Hennessy CEO in January 2020, and admittedly ‚Äúknew nothing about the Cognac industry‚Äù. His previous positions saw him gain a wealth of business experience in the 12 years he worked for Unilever, before he joined LVMH in 2002. At first, he oversaw the transformation of designer brand Guerlain, working as marketing director, then chairman and CEO from 2007. As of 2014, Boillot was also executive vice‚Äê president of Make Up For Ever.

Invaluable period

With the pandemic taking hold just a few months into Boillot‚Äôs move to Hennessy, the CEO found himself grounded in the region for nearly two years. But ever the optimist, Boillot reflects on this time as an invaluable period that allowed him to build his knowledge of the category.

‚ÄúInstead of travelling the whole world ‚Äì because Hennessy is present in more than 160 countries ‚Äì my home base for almost two years has been Cognac,‚Äù he explains. ‚ÄúI realised that something so important to us is the viticulture; we are certain we can create the best Cognac, coming from the best soils, coming from the best winegrowers.‚Äù

The pandemic caused a slight dip in sales for Hennessy in 2020, as volume sales went from more than 8 million cases in 2019 to 7.8m in 2020. However, the brand bounced back stronger than ever in 2021, and reported 9.2% volume growth to hit 8.6m cases.

‚ÄúWhen the wind is under you, you want to take the wind,‚Äù Boillot says. ‚ÄúWe are pushing as much as we can. We know there are many clouds coming ‚Äì the health issue is still there, the logistics issue is there, inflation, which is huge, and all the signs show there will probably be a recession some day. But you don‚Äôt decide that day, you don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going to happen, or the magnitude; so more than ever, it‚Äôs about preparing to be ready in case there is a crisis. If there is, we‚Äôll face it like before. But for the moment, it‚Äôs full speed ahead.‚Äù

Hennessy has long taken pride in its strong marketing initiatives and partnerships. To tap into the brand‚Äôs current momentum further, the Cognac house opened a permanent retail shop in luxury London department store Harrods in early June.

‚ÄúThe idea was to get closer to consumers, and also to better serve them,‚Äù says Boillot about when the idea was conjured. ‚ÄúThat brought me to pay a visit to Michael Ward [managing director at Harrods] ‚Äì it should have been a physical visit but it was a Zoom visit in 2020 ‚Äì and I asked Michael, why do you not have a Hennessy space in the greatest department store in the world, to try and develop the category in your store?‚Äù

Two years later, and the vision became reality as the Hennessy Boutique took its place on the lower ground floor of the store, in London‚Äôs Knightsbridge. The space is dedicated to the rarest Hennessy Cognacs, such as Hennessy Paradis.

Harrods‚Äô clientele is the ideal customer for such a boutique, Boillot and Board believe, with consumers flocking from around the world to shop there. Harrods‚Äô customers seek ‚Äúto get the best of the best ‚Äì not only products, but services‚Äù, notes Boillot. ‚ÄúThis is precisely why we wanted to focus more on the top range of our portfolio, and particularly Paradis, one of the finest products of the maison. It‚Äôs one of the rarest because of the blend; this is made of eaux‚Äê de‚Äêvie that can be a century old. We wanted to bring the rarest blends to the consumer.‚Äù

The opening of the shop coincided with a special bottling made exclusively for Harrods. The ‚Äòone‚Äêof‚Äêa‚Äêkind‚Äô Cognac comprised some of Hennessy‚Äôs ‚Äòrarest eaux‚Äê de‚Äêvie‚Äô, presented in a limited edition Dame Jeanne that was created in collaboration with artist Nelly Saunier.

Shoppers can also make use of the Hennessy Hands personalisation service. Boldly coloured leather bottle tags can be embossed while shoppers wait at the boutique. This is offered to add an extra element of uniqueness to purchases and to the overall shopping experience.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not only about the product but services, and this is precisely why we wanted to focus more on the high‚Äêend range of our portfolio, and particularly Paradis,‚Äù says Boillot.

Hennessy‚Äôs ongoing partnership with the National Basketball Association (NBA) has also been important to aiding the brand‚Äôs growth. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not your usual sponsorship story,‚Äù insists Boillot. Hennessy became the first global spirits partner of the NBA in February 2021, when it signed a multi‚Äêyear agreement to be the ‚Äòofficial spirit of the NBA‚Äô. The collaboration, which built on the North American deal announced in February 2020, comprises a range of consumer activations worldwide, and localised content.

‚ÄúThe reason why we selected the NBA and basketball is I don‚Äôt think there is another sport that is offering something that is necessary for us,‚Äù explains Boillot. ‚ÄúMost sports are about what is happening on the court, on the field, the activity in the arena. Basketball has such excitement in the game, but also great excitement off court; it‚Äôs the culture of the NBA. There are a billion fans of NBA on the planet, and they are global ‚Äì 200m fans are Chinese citizens, fans in America, the UK. Understand, basketball is the second‚Äêlargest sport in the UK.‚Äù

Last year, Hennessy launched a campaign starring American basketball player Russell Westbrook, called ‚ÄòMake Moves That Start Movements‚Äô. The creative push stars Westbrook alongside artist Victor Solomon, and Alex Taylor, founder of women‚Äôs basketball community group Hoop York City. The film depicts the journey of a basketball, and looked at communities that are forwarding the culture of the game.

Spots like this help Hennessy elevate its name among NBA fans, and recruit new drinkers, Boillot says. ‚ÄúWhat I sense, is when you speak about the NBA fans, it is a sport that is able to bring together so many people from different positions; under‚Äêprivileged, different types of backgrounds and ethnicities,‚Äù Boillot says.

But the relationship with the basketball league extends much further than this. Hennessy and the NBA have taken their influence into local communities worldwide as part of the ‚ÄòHennessy in the Paint‚Äô initiative, which combines art and sport, reviving neglected basketball courts in underprivileged areas.

‚ÄúSocial elements are also part of what Hennessy has always done; it‚Äôs about giving back,‚Äù Boillot says. ‚ÄúThe programme started in 2021 and is developing fast. We are in six countries so far, and by the end of the year we will have restored 15 courts worldwide, in Canada, South Africa and more, we will go everywhere. Each time we ask a local artist to design the court with us, so it‚Äôs a way to bond with the culture, and to give the country the opportunity to express itself.‚Äù

Most recently, Hennessy enhanced the digital aspect of its Make Moves That Start Movements campaign with an immersive online space, called Hennessy House of Moves. The digital ‚Äòhouse‚Äô, features three virtual floors, where users can access a performance by American rapper Gunna, and NBA‚Äêthemed Hennessy cocktails.

Hennessy NFTs

The power of digital has become ubiquitous over the past two years. Hennessy harnessed its digital prowess further this year with the launch of its first NFTs via online marketplace Blockbar. The first and last bottles of Hennessy 8 Cognac, of which 250 numbered bottles were released in 2017, were made available as NFTs, priced at 70.47 ethereum (US$226,450).

NFTs are sparking widespread debate in the spirits industry; but for Boillot, their purpose is simple: to attract new drinkers to discover Hennessy, offer traceability and proof of ownership.

‚ÄúPersonally, my wake‚Äêup call [to NFTs] was more than a year ago. I said to the company, we have to look at it, we have to understand it, we have to get into it and make our own way on this one,‚Äù Boillot says. ‚ÄúThere are elements we are not interested in, and some elements we are interested in.‚Äù

Boillot makes it crystal clear the company is not interested in launching NFTs as a cryptocurrency investment. ‚ÄúWhat we are interested in is using NFTs as an entry door to get to our consumers or to new consumers,‚Äù he explains. ‚ÄúWherever our consumer is, we have to go there to connect with them, engage with them. What‚Äôs really important to us is to use the digital world to bring those people into the regular world. That‚Äôs what I‚Äôm looking at. So launching an NFT, why not? But under the condition that it‚Äôs a key to get to the consumers and to bring them to the real world, because the real world is fantastic.‚Äù

Boillot says he takes the brand‚Äôs mission ‚Äòto preserve, to enrich and to transmit‚Äô ‚Äúvery seriously‚Äù. Improving Hennessy‚Äôs sustainability is an imperative aspect of this pledge, and something Boillot and his team plan to continue working on. Parent company Mo√´t Hennessy has set ambitious goals to cut its greenhouse gas emissions by 50% in absolute value by 2030 compared with 2019, as part of its sustainability programme, Living Soils Living Together.

Hennessy and its winegrowers have close to 80,000 hectares of vineyards altogether, Boillot says, and there is still room to grow more. ‚ÄúWe plant at a decent pace. We encourage the winegrowers to plant more, not too much, just to grow in the long term,‚Äù he notes.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to look like one of those ‚Äògreenwashers‚Äô,‚Äù he continues. ‚ÄúWe take sustainability very seriously for a simple reason: if we don‚Äôt protect the soil that is giving the eaux‚Äêde‚Äêvie, if we don‚Äôt protect the forest that is giving the oak and the barrels to make the eaux‚Äêde‚Äêvie, there is no future for our brand. So we do it selfishly to protect ourselves, but also with a sense of altruism because as a big company we believe that it is also our duty to do our share for the planet. We have a big programme about what viticulture should be and what it should look like in years to come.‚Äù

Long-term strategies

For Boillot, regardless of short‚Äêterm pivots as challenges arise, the future success of Hennessy will largely depend on the company‚Äôs long‚Äêterm strategies.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm always looking at the long‚Äêterm future, especially when it comes to eaux‚Äêde‚Äêvie, vineyards, the winegrowers,‚Äù Boillot insists. ‚ÄúWe are still buying as much eaux‚Äêde‚Äêvie as we can; we are still building cellars in Cognac because we believe whatever the crisis, we must plan for another 10, 20, 30, 50 years. The company has been there for 260 years and we believe it will be there for centuries to come.‚Äù

I ask Boillot what his views are on the future of Cognac. ‚ÄúG‚Äêr‚Äêe‚Äêa‚Äêt, great,‚Äù Boillot laughs. With sales of Cognac up by 31% in 2021, reaching ‚Ç¨3.6 billion (US$4.1bn), according to the Bureau National Interprofessionnel du Cognac, he is understandably upbeat about the category‚Äôs outlook, and there is much to look forward to in the years to come.

Titre: Paris 2024 Olympics: LVMH's long-awaited sponsorship sign-on - Le Monde
Contenu:
"If we have LVMH, we're good." This short phrase, uttered by an expert on the Paris 2024 Games, sums up the mindset among private and public players in the Olympic and Paralympic event (July 26 to August 11, then August 28 to September 8).

To complete its sponsorship budget ‚Äì ‚Ç¨1.115 billion or about 30% of its total budget ‚Äì the Organizing Committee for the Olympic and Paralympic Games (COJOP) has no choice but to find a new top-tier partner; in other words, they must be ready to pay more than ‚Ç¨100 million. It's "an imperative necessity," as the audit committee, chaired by Jacques Lambert, told the head of Paris 2024, Tony Estanguet, in late June.

The "target" has been identified: LVMH. Discussions with the world's number one luxury goods company, chaired by Bernard Arnault, France's richest man, are underway. But they are taking time, and both COJOP and the public authorities are waiting for a formal signature.

Signing a deal with LVMH (‚Ç¨64 billion in revenue, of which 93% are generated abroad, and 175,000 employees worldwide, of which 34,000 are in France) would represent a breath of fresh air for the COJOP, which must present, in a context of high inflation, an updated version of its budget (about ‚Ç¨4 billion) at its board meeting on December 12. This would be all the more significant as the group would be making a significant contribution, whereas other so-called premium partners ‚Äì such as the French retail giant Carrefour at the beginning of the summer ‚Äì have offered to provide goods and services to lighten the bill.

However, the French manufacturer, which owns Mo√´t & Chandon, would also be able to supply bottles of champagne or have Olympic medals made in the workshops of one of its jewelry brands. When contacted by Le Monde, LVMH did not wish to comment on this information. Paris 2024, which also did not have any comment, assured that it is in advanced negotiations with other lower-tier partners. But the organizer of the Games is essentially in a race against time: It has set itself the goal of closing 80% of its partnerships by the end of 2022.

Unparalleled media exposure

The balance of power is favorable to the French luxury giant, argues someone involved in the Olympic project, according to whom, "LVMH does not need the Games." However, joining Paris 2024 would provide the manufacturer with an unparalleled level of media exposure: In less than two years, 4 billion viewers are expected, and nearly 10 million spectators are expected in the streets of the capital, some of whom ‚Äì the wealthiest ‚Äì will pass through the doors of its retail outlets. As it happens, the Louis Vuitton store on the Champs-Elys√©es (with estimated sales of ‚Ç¨200 million) is scheduled to undergo an expansion by 2024.
